page.title: 05Newquay Harbour
page.content:
The heyday of Newquay harbour was in the nineteenth century.Richard Lomax excavated an eighty yard tunnel in the cliff in 1841 to allow china clay wagons to be brought directly to the harbour.Before then the harbour had been used only to fish for pilchards.
Now the harbour is used for a small amount of fishing boats which catch mainly crabs,lobsters and crayfish.
Fishing and exporting china clay and ore are no longer major industries and pleasure boats are replacing the trawlers.
The tramtracks,which previously brought the china clay to the harbour, are no longer in use,but there are still traces of them and the tunnel.
